newsitem.title: USA: U.S. FTC objects to ADP acquisition of AutoInfo.
newsitem.headline: U.S. FTC objects to ADP acquisition of AutoInfo.

text.p: U.S. regulators said on Thursday they were seeking an order to require Automatic Data Processing Inc to divest enough assets to restore competition in the salvage information management industry.

The Federal Trade Commission said ADP's acquisition of AutoInfo Inc in 1995 had created a monopoly that had raised prices and reduced the quality of service in the car salvage yard information management industry,

ADP, Roseland, N.J., which had $3 billion in revenues in 1995, provides information services and develops and sells computerized information systems to a variety of industries, including auto salvage yards and insurance companies.

The FTC said ADP acquired AutoInfo in April 1995, but later paid a $2.97 million civil penalty to resolve federal charges that its statutorily-required filing for pre-merger antitrust review was deficient, omitting for example documents that showed among other things that:
- there was an anticompetitive intent underlying the proposed acquisition;
- that the proposed acquisition would create serious compeititive concerns;
- and that ADP believed the acquisition would give it a monopoly or virtual monopoly in several product markets.

The FTC said it alleged in its administrative complaint that "the acquisition was part of an ADP plan to acquire the leading information service providers to the salvage industry and thereby acquire monopoly power."
Included in ADP's plan was the acquisition of Hollander Inc., completed in 1992, and of AutoInfo, the agency said.
It said an administrative hearing would be scheduled soon.
